p: The sequence of phase transformations of the major rock‐forming minerals with increasing temperature and pressure in the Earth's mantle is relatively well understood. The most abundant mineral in the upper mantle, olivine, transforms to wadsleyite at 410 km (approximately 14 GPa; Katsura et al., 2004), which then transforms to ringwoodite at 520 km ( ≈18 GPa near 1600 K; Katsura & Ito, 1989; Akaogi et al., 1989). The second most abundant mineral, orthopyroxene, undergoes gradual transformation (completed in the pressure interval 14‐16 GPa) to majorite garnet through the reaction with pyrope garnet (e.g., Irifune, 1987; Ringwood, 1991). Then ringwoodite and majorite react to form a mixture of bridgmanite and ferropericlase (at approximately 23‐24 GPa; Hirose, 2002). Through these phase transformations, the minerals change to denser crystal structures. These changes are sometimes associated with a change in the coordination of oxygen ions surrounding a cation, in particular silicon (Finger & Hazen, 1991).
